TITLE: United States of America vs Union Oil Company of California. U. S. District Court, N. D. California Civ. No. 72-1866 GBH. [Ownership rights of geothermal steam and resources for public land leases; Stock Raising Homestead Act]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LEGAL ASPECTS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; OWNERSHIP; CALIFORNIA; CASE LAW; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAND LEASING; LAWS; MINERALS; PUBLIC LANDS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; LEASING; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; USA; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The United States filed suit seeking a declaration of its ownership rights in the geothermal steam and associated geothermal resources being produced by certain defendants under leases from other defendants. The United States also sought injunctive relief and damages. On a defense motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted, and on a countermotion of the United States for summary judgment, the District Court, George B. Harris, Senior Judge, held that (1) what passed under a Stock Raising Homestead Act patent was fee title, not just the surface estate with a reservation of the subsurface, and (2) the Act's reservation of ''coal and other minerals'' to the United States did not include a reservation of geothermal steam and associated geothermal resources, since they are not ''minerals'' within the meaning of the reservation of the Act and the patents granted thereunder.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fed. Suppl.; (United States); Journal Volume: 369

TITLE: Geothermal resource energetics
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT EXTRACTION; FLUID FLOW; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RESOURCES; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The discussion covers the theory of geothermal heat extraction on the basis of three simple idealized models (single fracture flow, intergranular flow, and intergranular vaporization); theoretical expressions for the total available specific resource energy per unit area or unit volume; and illustrations comprising a number of numerical data useful in the assessment of the potential of individual geothermal resources.
RESEARCH_ORG: Oregon State Univ., Corvallis
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:3

TITLE: Geothermal energy prospects
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; POWER POTENTIAL; FORECASTING; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; IMPERIAL VALLEY; LONG VALLEY; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The overall environmental effects of geothermal resource use appear to be potentially less adverse than those of fossil fuel or nuclear energy operations, according to the U.S. Department of the Interior's final Environmental Impact Statement on the development of geothermal steam resources in the Federal lands of the western U.S. Under existing technology, geothermal steam is expanded into a low-pressure turbine, which drives a conventional electric generator. In some areas, the geothermal reservoir produces natural dry steam that can be brought to the surface and introduced directly into the turbine. In other areas, geothermal fluids (superheated and under pressure) are brought to the surface; a portion of the fluid flashes into steam, which is used to drive the turbine. The geothermal energy percentage of total national electrical power capacity by 2000 is estimated variously at 1 percent to 20 percent or more. The ultimate capacities of the Geysers field, the Imperial Valley area, and the Mono Lake/Long Valley area, Calif., are estimated to be 1000 to 5000, 3000 to 30,000, and 1750 Mw, respectively.
RELATION: Journal Name: Instrum. Control Syst.; (United States); Journal Volume: 47:2

TITLE: Development of geothermal resources and the 1970 Geothermal Steam Act: law in search of definition
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LEGAL ASPECTS; OWNERSHIP; LEASING; MINERALS; REVIEWS; DOCUMENT TYPES; RESOURCES; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 510600 - Environment, Terrestrial- Regulations- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: It is submitted that the court erred in U.S. vs Union Oil Company (Calif. 1974), by: (1) failing to find that Congress intended the Stock Raising Homestead Act to grant an estate limited to surface use with such subsurface rights as reasonably necessary to serve the purpose of surface ownership and (2) in inferentially treating geothermal resources as water resources to arrive at the conclusion that geothermal resources were not reserved because water is not a mineral within terms of the Stock Raising Homestead Act. Alternate legal concepts are suggested. (PCS)
RESEARCH_ORG: Northern Kentucky State Coll., Covington
RELATION: Journal Name: Univ. Colo. Law Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 46

TITLE: Extracting minerals from geothermal brines: a literature study. [USA, western region]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; EXPLORATION; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; MINERALS; RECOVERY; NATURAL STEAM; BRINES; CORROSION PROTECTION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; EROSION; EVAPORATORS; POWER GENERATION; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; REVIEWS; SOLAR PONDS; USA; WELL DRILLING; DOCUMENT TYPES; DRILLING; EQUIPMENT; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; NORTH AMERICA; PONDS; SOLAR COLLECTORS; SOLAR EQUIPMENT; STEAM; SURFACE WATERS; 150700* - Geothermal Energy- Products & By-Products; 150100 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: The U.S. Bureau of Mines is concerned with extracting minerals from residual geothermal brines after their heat content and some demineralized water have been recovered. This literature study is based on a survey of the literature and discussions with individuals knowledgeable on various aspects of the subject. This report examines the potential of the domestic geothermal mineral resources, considers the technical problems involved, and outlines possible effects on the environment from reservoir fluid withdrawal and reinjection. Geothermal resources in the western U.S. were extensively explored during the 1960s. Limited development operations included exploratory drilling and operating wells producing hot brine, separating steam for experimental electric power generation, and recovering minerals in solar evaporation ponds or in extraction plants. Interest in the recovery of minerals and salts from geothermal fluids waned because of corrosion and scaling problems and low or no market value of the mineral products. Most of these problems can be controlled with existing technology and careful planning of processes and equipment. (67 refs.)
RELATION: Journal Name: Inf. Circ. - U.S., Bur. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 8638
JOURNAL_NAME: Inf. Circ. - U.S., Bur. Mines; (United States)

TITLE: Simulation of geyser systems
AUTHORS: Merzhanov, A G; Steynberg, A S; Steynberg, G S
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEYSERS; SEISMIC EFFECTS; SIMULATION; EQUILIBRIUM; FLUID FLOW; STRUCTURAL MODELS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: The system is shown to be in a nonequilibrium metastable stage before the liquid ejection; in P-T coordinates, the liquid in the working chamber of the geyser has a temperature appreciably above that corresponding to the pressure in the chamber. The equilibrium is restored during the ejection, but it again is disrupted afterwards. A study has been made of the response of a geyser model to seismic effects, and it has been found that the metastability of the liquid in the system is due to the high sensitivity of the geyser state to seismic vibrations. Cavitation arises in the superheated liquid in response to the weak seismic vibrations, which leads to ejection. The relationship between the superheating and the threshold seismic energy for ejection is derived, and it is found that a linear temperature increase in the working chamber corresponds to exponential fall in the seismic energy necessary to initiate an ejection. A physical explanation has been given for the reported change in the natural period of a geyser before strong earth tremors in the adjacent region. It is found that the increase in the stress concentration in the crust regularly influences the natural period of the geyser. The trend can be used for seismic forecasting.
RESEARCH_ORG: Volcanology Inst., Moscow
RELATION: Journal Name: Geochem. Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:1; Other Information: Translated from Geokhimiya; No. 2, 277-290(1974)

TITLE: Corrosion resistance of chrome--nickel steels of the type 21Cr5Ni in sea water
AUTHORS: Korovin, Yu M; Ulanovskii, I B
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CHROMIUM-NICKEL STEELS; CORROSION RESISTANCE; SEAWATER; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; CARBON; CORROSION; PH VALUE; ALLOYS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM ALLOYS; CHROMIUM STEELS; ELEMENTS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; NICKEL ALLOYS; NONMETALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; STEELS; WATER; 360105* - Metals & Alloys- Corrosion & Erosion; 150903 - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: Data on the corrosion of integral and welded specimens of steels with 21 percent chromium; for comparison we have chosen steel /sup 18/Cr/sup 9/NiTi. The integral and welded specimens were quenched in water from 1000, 980, 1000, 1000, 1080 C. The pH of the water was reduced by adding HCl. In seawater, corrosion was local: failure arose mainly under the acorn barnacles--about 85 percent. No intercrystalline corrosion was observed. Except in the case of /sup 21/Cr/sup 6/Ni/sup 2/MoTi, which was 2-3 times more stable owing to presence of molybdenum, the corrosion of the integral specimens differed little. Increasing the carbon content of steel /sup 21/Cr/sup 5/Ni from 0.04 to 0.12 percent led to about a 15 percent increase in corrosion, reduction of nickel to 3 percent did not affect the stability of the steel. Chemical composition had a more marked influence in the welded specimens. The corrosion of the welded specimens was 1.5-2 times greater than that of the integral ones. There were no grounds for intensification of corrosion under the acorn barnacles of any of the zones in question. Thus, the pH at which there was a sudden marked shift of the potential toward the negative and the potentials at these pH values for the bulk metal, the zone near the seam and the weld seam were fairly close together. From the observed characteristics we cannot explain the greater corrosion of welded specimens in comparison with the integral ones. This phenomenon is due to the fact that under seawater the weld seam, owing to the rough surface, crevices rapidly arise, whereas on a smooth surface they arise only after a long time, because in these conditions acorn barnacles are attached very tightly.
RESEARCH_ORG: Inst. of Oceanology, Moscow
RELATION: Journal Name: Prot. Met. (USSR) (Engl. Transl.); (United States); Journal Volume: 10:5

TITLE: Developments in west coast area in 1972
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; NATURAL GAS; PRODUCTION; RESERVES; OREGON; PETROLEUM; WASHINGTON; DATA COMPILATION; EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; LEASING; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; STATISTICS; WEST COAST; DATA; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION IX; FEDERAL REGION X; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; INFORMATION; MATHEMATICS; MINERAL RESOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL DATA; RESOURCES; USA; WELLS; 020200* - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 030200 - Natural Gas- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 150300 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology; 020300 - Petroleum- Drilling & Production; 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing
DESCRIPTION: Exploratory activity in Washington increased substantially and was concentrated in the Puget Sound area where 4 unsuccessful wells were drilled. No well was drilled in Oregon, but there was leasing activity in central and E. areas of the State and drilling is likely in 1973. Exploratory drilling in California declined to the lowest level in 30 yr with only 186 wells completed, and for the first time new-field wildcats drilled primarily to find gas outnumbered those drilled to find oil. Nine gas discoveries included 3 important new fields. Seventeen oil discoveries included 2 new fields of undetermined significance. However, total credited additions to crude reserves were only 56.2% of 1972 production. Development drilling declined, as did production of both oil and gas. Effort to discover and exploit geothermal energy in the W. coast states continued at a high level, with both industry and public agencies participating. However, prospect drilling was restricted to California where in 3 areas 30 wells were drilled in 1972.
RESEARCH_ORG: Standard Oil Co California
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 57:8
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol., Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Environmentally sensitive land use regulation in California
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; LAND USE; LEGAL ASPECTS; CASE LAW; COASTAL REGIONS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DECISION MAKING; ENVIRONMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAWS; PLANNING; POLLUTION REGULATIONS; REGULATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; USA; 510600* - Environment, Terrestrial- Regulations- (-1989); 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: The thesis of this article is that by arguing analogously from the National Environmental Policy Act to California Environmental Quality Act to obtain adequate disclosure of adverse environmental effects from proposed land uses and by using the facts thus disclosed in making the requisite findings for the Coastal Zone Initiative (popularly known and Proposition 20) and other laws regulating new subdivisions, decision makers may be required to deny permits in certain environmentally sensitive areas that are currently under great development pressures. This paper also analyzes several California and non-California court cases to approach the issue of whether this denial constitutes an unconstitutional use of the police power. To fully comprehend the possible far-reaching effects of these statutes and cases an understanding of environmentally sensitive land use regulation, the participants in the systems, and the role of the courts in the local decision making is essential. (PCS)
RELATION: Journal Name: San Diego Law Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:4

TITLE: Geothermal power: sleeping giant stirs, but will require years to waken fully
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EVALUATION; CONTINENTAL CRUST; DEPTH; ELECTRIC POWER; HEAT TRANSFER; OCEANIC CRUST; PERMEABILITY; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RIFT ZONES; ROCKS; VOLCANIC REGIONS; WATER REQUIREMENTS; DIMENSIONS; EARTH CRUST; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY TRANSFER; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Although it is true that geothermal activity of one sort or another has been found in scores of countries, the major activity of interest for electric generation appears to concentrate along well-defined lines of volcanic action or rift valleys, where ridge systems in the ocean basin crusts pass under the continental crust. Unfortunately, nearly all these areas are remote from present electric load centers. Criteria for judging geothermal potential include: (1) fluid temperature over 150/sup 0/F; (2) depth no greater than 10,000 ft, to allow economic drilling; (3) good rock permeability, to let the heat exchange agent flow readily; and (4) water recharge to maintain production.
RELATION: Journal Name: Power; (United States); Journal Volume: 117:4

TITLE: Seismic noise measurements in a geothermal area
AUTHORS: Goforth, T T; Douze, E J; Sorrells, G G
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; SEISMIC SURVEYS; SEISMIC NOISE; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; SURVEYS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Generation of electrical power through the use of natural steam obtained from the Earth has the potential to be a significant source of pollution-free power. Successful future exploitation of geothermal power depends upon the development of cost-effective exploration techniques. A field experiment in the Imperial Valley of California indicates that there is a close empirical relationship between hot water deposits at depth and an anomalously high seismic background level at the surface. If this relationship proves to be a general one, it will serve as the basis of a simple and inexpensive method of geothermal exploration.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophys. Prospect.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:1

TITLE: Geothermal energy: geology, exploration, and developments. II
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ICELAND; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ITALY; JAPAN; MEXICO; NEW ZEALAND; USSR; BIBLIOGRAPHIES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; GEOCHEMISTRY; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; MAPS; REVIEWS; USA; ASIA; AUSTRALASIA; CHEMISTRY; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989); 150102 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Part 2 is a review of the geology and geothermal energy development in the following countries, which are currently commercially producing electric power from geothermal steam: United States, Iceland, Italy, Japan, Mexico, New Zealand, and Russia. Six other countries should have geothermal energy production in a few years, and at least 19 others are in the investigative stages. Current economics and governmental legislation in the United States are summarized. A select bibliography on the geology and exploration for geothermal energy in significant areas of the world is included.
RESEARCH_ORG: Colorado School of Mines, Golden
RELATION: Journal Name: Colo. Sch. Min., Miner. Ind. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 15:1

TITLE: Economic evaluation of Reykjanes thermal brine area, Iceland
AUTHORS: Bjornsson, S; Arnorsson, S; Tomasson, J
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; BY-PRODUCTS; ICELAND; BRINES; MINERAL RESOURCES; CALCIUM CHLORIDES; DEPTH; DESALINATION; GEOLOGY; HIGH TEMPERATURE; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; SALINITY; SODIUM CHLORIDES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM HALIDES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DEMINERALIZATION; DIMENSIONS; EUROPE; FLUIDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; RESOURCES; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; 150700* - Geothermal Energy- Products & By-Products
DESCRIPTION: The Reykjanes thermal brine area is located in southwestern Iceland on the subaerial continuation of the Reykjanes Ridge. This area is unique among thermal areas for its fluid composition. In the reservoir, where temperatures are 250-290/sup 0/C, the brine has a salinity equal to seawater. However, the concentrations of some ions are different and can be explained by relatively simple interaction of seawater with the rock. The trace metal content is low. In the upflow zone, hot brine has been exchanged repeatedly during the life of the system. Surface activity covers an area of 1 km/sup 2/, and a resistivity survey indicated that the system is of similar area above 900 m within the hyaloclastite formation where it is surrounded by cold groundwater of oceanic composition. By contrast, the system is more extensive in the underlying basalt formation of lava flows and thick interbeds of hyaloclastites and sediments. At 2600 m depth, Vp increases from 4.2 to 6.5 km/s. At this depth, the basalt formation is underlain by a denser formation considered to be similar to the 'oceanic layer.' Because of its temperature and composition, feasibility studies indicate that the brine could be economically exploited for production of NaCl, KCl, CaCl/sub 2/, and possibly other components. Aquifers are abundant in the basalt formation. Therefore, it is recommended that production wells penetrate to depths of about 2000 m to withdraw brine from this permeable formation, so as to ensure the highest mass-flow and to minimize the risk of cold seawater intrusion.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 56:12
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Salt water is a mineral: ownership of a natural resource of increasing importance in oil-producing states
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; MINERALS; LEGAL ASPECTS; BRINES; CASE LAW; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; MINING; OWNERSHIP; PETROLEUM; PRODUCTION; SALTS; SOLUTIONS; TEXAS; DISPERSIONS; ENERGY SOURCES; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; LAWS; MIXTURES; NORTH AMERICA; USA; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 510500 - Environment, Terrestrial- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989); 510600 - Environment, Terrestrial- Regulations- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Salt water, a resource with newfound promise, defies easy allocation between the surface and mineral estates. The author, relying on history, precedents, and policy, contends that salt water should be classified as a mineral belonging to the mineral owner whereas domestic water should be considered a nonmineral appurtenant to the surface estate.
RELATION: Journal Name: Tex. Law Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 50

DESCRIPTION: From decisions of the tax court, 52 T.C. 700, favorable to taxpayers, an appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Wright, Circuit Judge, held that taxpayers' reserves of geothermal steam constituted an exhaustible natural resource and that geothermal steam was a ''gas'' within meaning of Internal Revenue Code provisions for percentage depletion deduction for intangible costs of drilling and developing oil and gas wells.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fed. Rep.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:454

TITLE: Composition of the magmatic gas of Kilauea and its behavior in the near surface environment
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; FUMAROLIC FLUIDS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; HAWAII; VOLCANOES; CARBON DIOXIDE; DATA; GASES; MAGMA; MAGMATIC WATER; SULFUR OXIDES; TABLES; VOLCANISM; WATER VAPOR; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GROUND WATER; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; ROCKS; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; USA; VAPORS; WATER; WESTERN REGION; 580202* - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Kilauea gas collections are used to calculate the composition of the magmatic gas from which they were derived. Atmospheric contamination is present in all samples. Removal of atmospheric gases by four methods results in four atomic compositions; these are used to compute four equilibrium (molecular) compositions for each sample. Simultaneous consideration of atmospheric and water contaminations defines the best method of atmospheric gas removal and shows that all variations in hydrogen content are due to contaminating water. Calculations also indicate that the carbon content of the magmatic gas is not significantly changed; large differences in sulfur are due to changes in SO/sub 2/. When all modifying processes are considered simultaneously, all differences in sample compositions are accounted for. The changes caused by these processes are ''reversed'' to return each sample to its magmatic composition; all samples yield the same composition. The original analyses are then examined for the degree to which they approach equilibrium. Although none of the analyses is an equilibrium composition, each was at equilibrium at magmatic temperatures. Imperfect quenching and oxidation after collection caused nonequilibrium. Various groups of gases have different reaction rates and exhibit a ''spectrum of quenching temperatures.'' H/sub 2/O contamination occurred after quenching. Volumetric comparisons are made to assess the magnitude of compositional changes and their overall chemical effects.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Arizona, Tucson
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 271:5

TITLE: Magnesium ion concentrations in the presence of magnesium chlorite, calcite, carbon dioxide, quartz
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BROADLANDS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOCHEMISTRY; CALCITE; ROCK-FLUID INTERACTIONS; CHLORITE MINERALS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; KAWERAU GEOTHERMAL FIELD; MAGNESIUM; ABUNDANCE; QUARTZ; WAIOTAPU GEOTHERMAL FIELD; WAIRAKEI GEOTHERMAL FIELD; CARBON DIOXIDE; DATA; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MAGNESIUM IONS; PHASE STUDIES; TABLES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; THERMAL WATERS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; ATOMIC IONS; CALCIUM CARBONATES; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CARBONATES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHARGED PARTICLES; CHEMISTRY; ELEMENTS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; INFORMATION; IONS; METALS; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions; 150302 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Concentrations of magnesium were measured in solutions in contact with magnesium chlorite, calcite, and quartz, under carbon dioxide pressures of 5 and 65 atm, and at temperatures from 190 to 300/sup 0/C. Magnesium concentrations were of the order of 0.5 to 1 ppM at 200/sup 0/C and 0.02 to 0.05 ppM at 300/sup 0/C. Comparison is made between values of a/sub Mg//a/sub H/sup 2// from the experimental solutions and natural high-temperature waters.
RESEARCH_ORG: Dept. of Scientific and Industrial Research, Petone, New Zealand
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 271:5

TITLE: Geothermal energy: Geology, exploration, and developments. Part I
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOCHEMICAL SURVEYS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; GEOLOGY; USA; ARIZONA; CALIFORNIA; COLORADO; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GRAVITY SURVEYS; HEAT FLOW; IDAHO; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; MAPS; MONTANA; NEVADA; NEW MEXICO; OREGON; PETROLOGY; REVIEWS; SEISMIC SURVEYS; TECTONICS; UTAH; VOLCANISM; WASHINGTON; WYOMING; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EXPLORATION; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SOUTHWEST REGION; WESTERN REGION; Geothermal Legacy; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 150300 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology
DESCRIPTION: Geology, exploration, and initial developments of significant geothermal areas of the world are summarized in this report which is divided into two parts. Part 1 is a review of the geological and explorational aspects of geothermal energy development; areas of potential development in the Western United States are also discussed. The most favorable geological environment for exploration and development of geothermal steam is characterized by recent normal faulting, volcanism, and high heat flow. Successful exploration for steam consists of coordinated multidisciplinary application of geological, geophysical, and geochemical knowledge and techniques. These are reviewed. California leads in known geothermal reserves and is followed by Nevada, Oregon, and New Mexico. Specific prospective areas in these 11 Western States are described.
RESEARCH_ORG: Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO
RELATION: Journal Name: Colo. Sch. Min., Miner. Ind. Bull. (United States); Journal Volume: 14:6
JOURNAL_NAME: Colo. Sch. Min., Miner. Ind. Bull. (United States)

TITLE: Geothermal resources leasing and operations on public, acquired, and withdrawn lands. II
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LEGAL ASPECTS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; LAND LEASING; REGULATIONS; PUBLIC LANDS; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LEASES; RECOMMENDATIONS; US DOI; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; LEASING; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; US ORGANIZATIONS; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 510600 - Environment, Terrestrial- Regulations- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Text of proposed amendments to existing regulations and procedures to be followed in conducting exploration of the public land for oil and gas or geothermal resources are presented. Regulations are for implementation of the Geothermal Steam Act. Leasing subparts include definitions; geophysical exploration operations; available land, limitation, unit agreements; lessee qualification; leasing terms; surface management requirements; service charges, rental, and royalties; lease bonds; noncompetitive leases; land previously leased for geothermal resources; competitive leases; conversion rights to geothermal leases or application for leases; leasing rules; extension, assignments, and transfers; production and uses of by-products; cooperative conservation provisions; terminations and expirations. Operations subparts cover definitions, supervisor functions and jurisdiction; lessee (including operator) requirements relative to drilling and well operations for production, pollution control, noise abatement, safety and abandonment; measurement of production and computation of royalties; and required report. (PCS)
RELATION: Journal Name: Fed. Regist. (Wash., D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 36:142; Other Information: From Bureau of Land Management, 43CFR3000, 43CFR3045, 43CFR3200; 30CFR270, Dept. of the Interior. Notice of proposed rule making

TITLE: Prospecting by the geothermic method
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; GROUND WATER; HEAT FLOW; MINERAL SPRINGS; SENSITIVITY; THERMISTORS; THERMOMETERS; EXPLORATION; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; WATER; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging; 580203 - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A high sensitivity thermometer using a thermistor sensing element was designed for practical measurements in the field. The most suitable procedures for the elimination of diurnal and seasonal variation temperature, the influence of vegetation cover and of other effects were investigated. Positive results of geothermic measurements have been acquired on sulfide deposits. By far the most important results of geothermic measurements have been obtained in hydrogeological problems, e.g., the investigation of circulation of underground water. In the case of prospection for cold mineral waters the combination of geothermic measurements with gasometric analyses is very useful. As the classical domain for geothermic investigation, prospecting for hot water is mentioned.
RESEARCH_ORG: Inst. of Applied Geophysics, Prague, Czechoslovakia
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophys. Prospect.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:2

TITLE: Description and interpretation of phase relations in geochemical processes involving aqueous solutions
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ROCK-FLUID INTERACTIONS; PHASE STUDIES; SILICATES; SOLUBILITY; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; CARBONATES; EQUATIONS; EQUILIBRIUM; GEOCHEMISTRY; MINERALS; OXIDES; SODIUM CHLORIDES; SULFATES; SULFIDES; THERMODYNAMICS; WATER; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMISTRY; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; 152001* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: Sets of thermodynamic components consisting solely of oxide and/or sulfide formula units are not adequate to describe compatibilities and reactions among minerals in geologic systems involving natural aqueous solutions. Consideration of the compositional characteristics of such solutions and the extent to which they interact with rocks suggests that the chemical potentials of chloride components such as NaCl are commonly fixed by the composition of the aqueous phase. Under such conditions the chemical potentials of the corresponding oxide components are not independent variables but are controlled by the activity of the hydrogen ion. Recognition of the compositional constraints imposed by the aqueous phase on chemical reactions and equilibrium among phases in geologic systems leads to an integrated thermodynamic frame of reference for description and interpretation of phase relations, and prediction of mass transfer among silicates, sulfides, oxides, carbonates, sulfates, and aqueous solutions.
RESEARCH_ORG: Northwestern Univ., Evanston, IL
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 268

TITLE: Physico-chemical sampling of high temperature wells in connection with their encrustation by calcium carbonate
AUTHORS: Kryudov, P A; Larinov, E G
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALCIUM CARBONATES; DEPOSITION; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; TEMPERATURE LOGGING; EVAPORATION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; PH VALUE; PRECIPITATION; PROBES; SAMPLING; STAINLESS STEELS; THERMISTORS; USSR; WATER; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALLOYS; ASIA; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; CHROMIUM ALLOYS; CORROSION RESISTANT ALLOYS; EASTERN EUROPE; ENERGY SYSTEMS; EUROPE; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; SEPARATION PROCESSES; STEELS; WELL LOGGING; WELLS; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions; 150303 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging
DESCRIPTION: The most important practical problems of physical-chemical studies of high-thermal underground waters are connected with investigating the conditions of well encrustation due to calcium carbonate. A set of methods of high-thermal well sampling determines the state characteristics of carbonate equilibrium in water, the temperature, and the rate of forming calcium carbonate precipitate. These methods were used in the high-thermal water-fields of Bolshebanny and Pauzhetsky in Kamchatka and Goryachy Plazh (Hot Beach) on Kunashir Is. For water sampling of operating wells, a probe, a tube made of stainless steel, was used and inserted in the well through a gasket below the vaporization level. To measure pH in deep-seated water samples, the probe was connected to a high-temperature cell with a glass and reference electrodes mounted in autoclave where natural pressure and temperature conditions were created. A probe with a thermistor was applied for the continuous temperature measurement at different depth and for determining the position of vaporization zone in operating wells. The checking of the well encrustation process was done by means of measuring the internal diameter and the thickness of calcium carbonate layer encrusted on the probe lowered in the well.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 2

TITLE: Reich, Arthur E. and Carolyn C. Reich vs Commission of Internal Revenue, U. S. Tax Court, July 31, 1969. [Depletion allowances for intangible costs of drilling and developing geothermal steam wells]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; DEPLETION ALLOWANCES; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; TAXES; CASE LAW; FINANCING; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; LEGAL ASPECTS; WELL DRILLING; DRILLING; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EXPLORATION; LAWS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; WELLS; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation
DESCRIPTION: The petitioners participated in ventures to drill for and exploit geothermal steam. One of these ventures was successful and the resulting wells produced sufficient steam to supply electrical generating plants. One of the petitioners claimed percentage depletion against the gross income it received from steam production in the successful venture. All the petitioners expensed the intangible costs of drilling and developing geothermal steam wells. Held, the petitioner which participated in the successful venture, is entitled to deduct percentage depletion at the rate of 27/sup 1///sub 2/ percent against gross income it received from steam production. Held, further, all petitioners are entitled to expense the intangible costs of drilling and developing geothermal steam wells.
RELATION: Journal Name: Tax Court Rep.; (United States); Journal Volume: 52
